log.input:
According to the description, write Vpython code:

First, we need to set some parameters, including the radii, masses, charges, and colors of helium nuclei and gold nuclei. The radius of the helium nucleus is 0.4 nanometers, the mass is 4 atomic mass units, the charge is 2 elementary charges, and the color is red. The radius of the gold nucleus is 1 nanometer, the mass is 197 atomic mass units, the charge is 79 elementary charges, and the color is yellow. The initial velocity of the helium nucleus is set to 10 nanometers per nanosecond. The initial position of the helium nucleus is set at a vertical distance of 1 nanometer from the gold nucleus, and the screen width is set to 40 nanometers. We use a hypothetical electrostatic force constant, set to 1. Time starts from 0 nanoseconds, and the time step is set to 0.001 nanoseconds.

Next, we set up the animation window, and set the title, width, height, center, and background color. Create an animation window with the title "Rutherford Scattering", a width of 800 pixels, a height of 600 pixels, the center as the origin, and the background color as black.

Next, create the helium and gold nuclei, and set their positions, radii, masses, charges, and colors. The initial position of the helium nucleus is set to (-0.5 * L + r1, b, 0), with radius r1, mass m1, charge q1, initial velocity v0, color c1, and set to leave a trail during motion. The position of the gold nucleus is set to (0, 0, 0), with radius r2, mass m2, charge q2, and color c2.

To more clearly observe the motion of the helium nucleus, we also create arrows representing velocity and acceleration. The initial position of the velocity arrow is set at the position of the helium nucleus, the shaft width is set to half the radius of the helium nucleus, and the color is cyan. The initial position of the acceleration arrow is also set at the position of the helium nucleus, the shaft width is set to half the radius of the helium nucleus, and the color is magenta.

Next, create a chart of energy changes over time, and set the title, width, height, and titles for the x-axis and y-axis. The chart's title is "Energy - Time Plot", width is 600 pixels, height is 450 pixels, the x-axis title is "t", and the y-axis title is "red: K, green: U, blue: E". Define the curve colors for kinetic energy, potential energy, and total energy, with the kinetic energy curve in red, potential energy curve in green, and total energy curve in blue.

In the simulation part of the object's motion, we use a while loop to simulate the motion of the helium nucleus until it exits the screen range. By using rate(500), we control the speed of the animation. Within each time step, calculate the electrostatic force the helium nucleus experiences, and update its acceleration, velocity, and position based on this force. Calculate the electrostatic force F, update the helium nucleus's acceleration alpha.a, velocity alpha.v, and position alpha.pos. Update the positions and directions of the arrows representing velocity and acceleration, setting the shaft of the velocity arrow to the helium nucleus's velocity, and the shaft of the acceleration arrow to the helium nucleus's acceleration.

To track energy changes, calculate the kinetic energy K, the system's potential energy U, and the total energy E of the helium nucleus, and plot these values over time on the chart. The calculation formula for kinetic energy K is 0.5 * alpha.m * alpha.v.mag2, the calculation formula for potential energy U is k * alpha.q * au.q / alpha.pos.mag, and the total energy E is the sum of kinetic energy K and potential energy U. Plot these energy values on the chart with the kinetic energy curve in red, potential energy curve in green, and total energy curve in blue. As time progresses, continuously update the time variable t.

Finally, update the time variable t, and the loop continues until the helium nucleus exits the screen range.

Cyber Input Variable Mapping Information:

(1) Define and initialize a variable named Radius_I as a cyber input variable, set Radius_I=0.5

(2) Radius_I is the radius of the ball. When Radius_I changes to a new value, the radius of the ball also changes to that value.
(3) Do not import packages that are not supported by VPython such as numpy, math, sympy, scipy and time.

from vpython import *

# parameters
r1, m1, q1, c1 = 0.4e-9, 4, 2, color.red
r2, m2, q2, c2 = 1e-9, 197, 79, color.yellow
L, b, v0, k = 40e-9, 1e-9, 10e-9/1e-9, 1
dt, t = 1e-3, 0

# animation window
scene = canvas(title="Rutherford Scattering", width=800, height=600, center=vector(0,0,0), background=color.black)

# helium and gold nuclei
alpha = sphere(pos=vector(-0.5*L+r1, b, 0), radius=r1, m=m1, q=q1, v=vector(v0,0,0), color=c1, make_trail=True, trail_type="points", interval=10)
au = sphere(pos=vector(0,0,0), radius=r2, m=m2, q=q2, color=c2)

# velocity and acceleration arrows
alpha.v_arrow = arrow(pos=alpha.pos, axis=alpha.v, shaftwidth=0.5*r1, color=color.cyan)
alpha.a_arrow = arrow(pos=alpha.pos, axis=alpha.v, shaftwidth=0.5*r1, color=color.magenta)

# energy-time plot
gd = graph(title="Energy - Time Plot", width=600, height=450, xtitle="t", ytitle="red: K, green: U, blue: E")
K_curve = gcurve(graph=gd, color=color.red)
U_curve = gcurve(graph=gd, color=color.green)
E_curve = gcurve(graph=gd, color=color.blue)

while alpha.pos.x < 0.5*L:
    rate(500)
    r = alpha.pos - au.pos
    F = k * alpha.q * au.q * r.norm() / r.mag2
    alpha.a = F / alpha.m
    alpha.v += alpha.a*dt
    alpha.pos += alpha.v*dt
    alpha.v_arrow.pos = alpha.a_arrow.pos = alpha.pos
    alpha.v_arrow.axis = alpha.v
    alpha.a_arrow.axis = alpha.a
    K = 0.5*alpha.m*alpha.v.mag2
    U = k*alpha.q*au.q/alpha.pos.mag
    E = K + U
    K_curve.plot(pos=(t, K))
    U_curve.plot(pos=(t, U))
    E_curve.plot(pos=(t, E))
    t += dt
